Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: Collaborative Research: Building Sustainable Tools and Collaboration for Volcanic and Related Hazards

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on creating and upgrading software infrastructure for a large community of scientists engaged in volcanology research and associated hazard analysis. Specifically, the project will reengineer three widely used tools (TITAN2D - block and ash flows, TEPHRA and Puff - ash transport and dispersal) and develop support for workflows that use these tools to analyze risk from volcanic hazards. Reengineering will encompass modularization so researchers may easily experiment with different modeling approaches, incorporation of techniques to make the tools efficient on new computing architectures like GPUs and many-core chips. The workflows are intended to tackle the challenges of managing complex and often large data flows associated with these tools in validation processes and in probabilistic inference based on the outcomes of the modeling. The tools and workflows will be made available using the popular vhub.org platform. This project will help provide a standard well managed hardware/software platform and approaches to standardize the documentation associated with input data, source code, and output data. This will ensure that model calculations are reproducible.

The wider use of these high fidelity tools and their use in mitigating hazards is likely to have a significant effect on hazard analysis and management. The project will also engage in several major workshops and in training activities. Project personnel will also engage in the Earthcube initiative - popularizing computational methodologies, online access and dissemination mechanisms through the VHub platform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focussed on developing new tools for analysis of hazardous phenomena related to volcanic activity. 

a) TITAN2D, a tool for analysis of hazardous mass flows was redeveloped to include multiple rheologies necessary to model the complex fluid infiltrated flows often encountered. 

b) Uncertainty quantification methods were further developed and model ensembles were used to develop probabilistic assessment of hazard. These workflows were automated using the Pegasus workflow tool and deployed on the vhub.org platform for open access and usage.

c) Plume modeling tool bent and volcanic ash transport and dispersal tools puff and hysplit were integrated to provide integrated assesment of volcanic ash transport and probabilistic assessment of hazard.

d) New SPH based model of volcanic plumes -- Plume-SPH was developed and released open source.

e) New versions of popular TEPHRA2D tool for modeling of tephra dispersal was developed and disseminated.

f) Software methodologies for seamlessly incorporating multiple rheologies in the same numerical solver were developed.

g) Methodologies for combining outputs from multiple rheologies for more accurate simulations based on available observational data were developed.

h) Over 6 PhD dissertations (2 female and 1 Hispanic) and 3 postdoctoral fellows (1 female) were supported on this award. Multiple presentations were made to disseminate work.

i) Outcomes of project have informed NATO plans for developing airworthiness in environments with particulates in atmosphere.
